lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write short words and sentences (e.g., “Have you got a scooter?”) clearly and accurately.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Model: “Have you got a scooter?” on the board. Students copy carefully, focusing on spacing and punctuation.
stretchStrategies: ❝Write and Find Partner❞ – Students draw a toy and write a sentence: “Have you got a ___?” They walk around the room reading their question and answering classmates with “Yes, I have.” / “No, I haven’t.” They sit when they find a match.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and assign the correct toy to the correct person.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “He’s got a skateboard.” or “She hasn’t got a bat.” Students choose the correct toy/person from the SB.
stretchStrategies: ❝Write and Find Partner❞ – Students draw a toy and write a sentence: “Have you got a ___?” They walk around the room reading their question and answering classmates with “Yes, I have.” / “No, I haven’t.” They sit when they find a match.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to play a collaborative game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Turn-taking) In pairs, students ask: “Have you got a ___?” Classmate answers. Then they swap roles.

Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
